FacilityName: Helena Chemical Company - Seymour, IA Facility
SafetyInspectionBy: Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardshi

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Iowa Administrative Code 21-43.6 (200) - Standard for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Breakaway couplers at the riser; emergency shutoff valve at the pressure vessel (liquid) and at bulkhead (vapor).
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspection / Routine preventive maintenance & repair
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pressure Vessel, Pump, pump seals, pipes and plumbing, valves, electrical and safety equipment. The breakaway couplers, pressure relief valves and hoses are also inspected and replaced as necessary.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Operations Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Storage & Handling of anhydrous ammonia at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The Risk Management Program includes an Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, and Incident Investigation. Equipment included under this covered process includes (1) 18,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel and ancillary pump, piping, and valves; (16) 1,450-gallon nurse tanks and (10) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks. Helena personnel perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the pressure vessel to the nurse tanks in accordance with the Operating Procedures provided in the RMPr.



Helena receives anhydrous ammonia by a Contractor that transports the anhydrous ammonia with a commercial tanker truck. The commercial tanker truck is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the anhydrous ammonia is transferred to the stationary pressure vessel. The transfer process from the commercial truck is performed by the commercial tanker truck operator (Contractor). Helena does not own or operate the commercial tanker truck. The Contractor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation and training procedures and documentation.  At a minimum, the Contractor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT and OSHA regulations, (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading operations and that its OSHA and DOT programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan and RMPr for review upon request by the Contractor.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This Facility is non-responding and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Helena Seymour Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68. Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards.  However, the OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, are applicable and are included in the Risk Management Program (RMPr) document that is implemented by this Facility.



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Seymour Facility located approximately one (1) mile south of Seymour and approximately 0.1 mile east of intersection County Road S60 and East Garden Road (3310 East Garden Road).  This Facility is at a location that is remote to the Seymour Office which is located at 120 South Fourth Street, Seymour, IA 52590.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Seymour Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Seymour Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



This is a 5-year update.  Also, adjustments were made to the anhydrous ammonia inventory regarding nurse tanks.  These updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility Risk Management Plan Program Document (RMPr).



FACILITY



The Seymour Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility and operates one (1) covered process that includes Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transported to the Facility via a commercial tanker truck (9,600 gallon) and then transferr

ed to one (1) 18,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel.  The commercial tanker truck operator (Contractor) performs these transfer operations.  



Helena stores the anhydrous ammonia in the on-site stationary storage tanks and then transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the storage tank to nurse tanks at point of retail sale to the end user (e.g. the farmer).  This Facility owns and operates (16) 1,450-gallon nurse tanks and (10) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks.  Helena performs this operation in accordance with its RMPr accident prevention program.  



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the one covered process that is conducted at this Facility.  The covered process includes anhydrous ammonia Storage and Handling.  



The worst case scenario release for the Retail Facility assumed that all the contents in the largest single pressure vessel were released.  For this Facility, the largest vessel is an 18,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia pressure vessel was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the storage and handling covered process as well.  The alternative release for the Storage and Handling assumes a 0.5-minute release from a ruptured 3-inch transfer line caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer line during a major loading or unloading operation.  Mitigation systems included in this alternative scenario included the internal valve on the commercial tanker truck; excess flow valves (liquid and vapor ports) and emergency shutoff valve (liquid) at the pressure vessel; backflow check valve on the liquid piping and emergency shutoff valve on the vapor piping at the bulkhead; and operating procedures that Helena uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Operations Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Operations Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that Helena Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Prevention Program which includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Helena's Seymour Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Seymour Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Seymour

Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Seymour Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Wayne County LEPC and Seymour Fire Department.



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Seymour Facility.
